claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in areas with strong currents, which passively moves water over their gills.
Such resting behavior is rare and only possible in specific environments with strong currents, making it an exception rather than the norm.
Tiger sharks can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over their gills) when swimming slows, reducing their dependence on ram ventilation.
Buccal pumping is energetically costly and unsustainable for long periods, meaning tiger sharks still rely primarily on ram ventilation.

supporting.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they would suffocate due to lack of oxygen from water flow over their gills.

attacks.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they would suffocate due to lack of oxygen from water flow over their gills.
Tiger sharks, like other ram ventilators, can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over their gills) when swimming slowly or stationary.
Buccal pumping is energetically costly and cannot be sustained indefinitely, so tiger sharks would still suffocate if completely immobile for extended periods.
Some observations show tiger sharks resting motionless on the seafloor in areas with strong currents, suggesting passive gill ventilation is possible.
These observations are rare and may represent brief recovery periods rather than normal behavior, as most tiger sharks exhibit continuous swimming.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks lack the ability to pump water over their gills while stationary, unlike some other shark species.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks lack the ability to pump water over their gills while stationary, unlike some other shark species.
Tiger sharks can still passively absorb some oxygen through buccal pumping when stationary, though less efficiently.
Buccal pumping in tiger sharks is insufficient to meet their metabolic demands for extended periods.
Tiger sharks frequently rest near ocean currents that provide passive water flow over their gills.
Not all tiger shark habitats have reliable currents, making this adaptation inconsistent.

supporting.text: The physiology of tiger sharks is adapted for constant movement, and stopping would disrupt their respiratory function.

attacks.text: The physiology of tiger sharks is adapted for constant movement, and stopping would disrupt their respiratory function.
Some shark species, including tiger sharks, can utilize buccal pumping to breathe while stationary, reducing dependence on constant movement.
Buccal pumping is inefficient in tiger sharks compared to ram ventilation, making prolonged stops unsustainable for respiration.
Tiger sharks frequently rest near ocean currents or in areas with sufficient water flow, mitigating respiratory issues when stationary.
Such resting behaviors are rare and location-dependent, not representative of the species' general physiological constraints.
